Description: Rim and body fragment of large North Ionian black-figured pottery plate, with fairly deep bowl and wide, horizontally drawn-out rim; exterior: glaze bands; interior; yellow-cream slip: on outer edge of rim strokes; on top stopt maeander and squares; three bands around the tondo in which there remains the bent head of a flute-player, with cheek-band, to left; field ornament: dotted rosette; incision used for details and part of the outline of flute-player; drill hole on broken edge for analysis. Fairly coarse brown-orange clay with small amounts of silver mica.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (II D pl. 4, 18)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.732)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (no. 254, pl. 14)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
